data: Hey, I’m typewatch. I’m a student with an innate desire for knowledge. I’ve dabbled in various engineering fields along the years, and I built this website to store everything I have done so far.
data.contact-info#Contact Info: Github - typewatch Discord - typewatch Email - typewatch(at)proton(dot)me
data.website#Website:
This website was built with Hugo, is based on a custom theme named Hextra, and is hosted by GitHub.
To learn how to make your own website, check out these resources:
Github Pages Hugo Quickstart Hugo Themes Library

data:
Hey! I’m typewatch, a guy on the internet that likes to learn about interesting stuff. Coincidentally, I also make interesting stuff.
Welcome to my little corner of the internet! I made this website as a companion for my bigger projects; this’ll be where I store and organize writeups, details, resources, docs, guides, and whatnot. I might post a blog entry or two every now and then, too.
More to come soon, I think.
Welcome to my docs archive; here you can find in-depth information regarding almost all of my projects.
data.feedback#Feedback: I heavily appreciate feedback; please visit the about page for more information.

data:
Driver40 is an ultraportable, 4x5 ortholinear, low profile split keyboard. Handful of words huh? Here’s what they mean:
4x5: The keyboard is built with a 4-row, 5-column key configuration. ortholinear: The keys in the keyboard are low profile: split:
data.why#Why?:
I like split keyboards, and needed a portable keyboard to carry with me on a day-to-day basis. I have an MX lily58 at home, and I really like it, but sometimes when I’m away from my desk and I need to sit down and churn out some code, do homework, or just play a game, I miss the perfection that is
I looked around for a little while, and found nothing that caught my eye, so I decided to make my own. After all, I have previously done similar things, and I figured it’d be worth it since I would be able to fine-tune it to my liking.
I set forth a few things I wanted out of a keyboard, and got sketching. You can see the whole process in the more in-depth write-up found at driver40/devlog/, or at my website.
Driver40 is what I ended up with. I also implemented a few other nifty features and turned them into their own variations of the primary build, which you can see above.
